content: Hi @WG-traits! Meeting time!
Maybe give a :wave: if you're here?
can we add an event to the compiler calendar or somewhere?
Good idea. I was supposed to do that and didn't
Okay, so Niko and I prepared a document to outline what we should talk about this meeting
That's here: https://hackmd.io/kFwkoHhESjy9Locp_3HxUA
I'm a calendar oriented kind of person :)
Maybe everyone should give it a very quick skim?
And add any questions or thoughts to the bottom?
(it's very small lol)
Okay, so let's start by discussing the "traits team"
or T-types :)
I assume everyone has seen the other thread?
https://rust-lang.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/144729-wg-traits/topic/making.20a.20team.20for.20traits.2C.20polonius.2C.20etc
mostly, just skimmed over parts of it
Also Niko had a doc, let me find that link
https://hackmd.io/@nikomatsakis/rJ3h_-kJc
So, there's obviously a couple points that I had put in the "agenda" that I think are worth covering
But before we touch on those, did anyone have any thoughts or questions?
I guess :check: for no, :x: for yes?
Okay, so I guess we can quickly go through the points in the agenda
So, first was "motivation"
Somebody (I don't remember who, sorry!) brought up that they didn't fully grasp the motivation for this
I think Niko updated the doc a bit

But I think generally, the motivation here is "The typesystem, trait solver, and borrow checker are complex; having a unified team that can oversee the implementation and modeling of these is generally helpful"
Actually, I wouldn't just say helpful, but actually necessary?
I guess this kind of goes into to third point
well, right now it's pretty much unified teamniko
so we already have that, just in a worse way
Yeah, Niko is a rock star :)
But I think it's better if, in the long run, it's not a "only Niko knows how everything truly works and why"
(and without putting words in his mouth, I think he feels the same)
Having a higher bus factor is always good :)
Yes

yes, like, my point was that right now we already have entities which have a unified view of these areas. Not to say that it isn't needed, but to show that it is needed so badly that we ended up with an informal - and unsustainable - solution right now

Jack Huey said:

But I think it's better if, in the long run, it's not a "only Niko knows how everything truly works and why"

so, pretty much this xd
To also expand on motivation a bit: this team is that much different than what the current wg-traits does in practice
By that, I mean, we already sort of tackle a lot of types and traits questions
With "borrow checker" questions really getting diverted to either @WG-nll or @WG-polonius
But, in reality, borrow checking and such is strongly integrated into types
So, in my mind, T-types is more of a "formalization" (pun intended) of the actual "responsibilities" of wg-traits
Sliding into point three a bit: This team doesn't necessarily own the "surface syntax" of the Rust language
but more of how the Rust language works
The example Niko and I came up with was the recent discussion on "equality where clauses"
basically fn<T,U>() where T == U {}
Lang team might say "Oh, that looks awesome; definitely something that fits the language"
But types team would say "hold on a minute - there might be problems with that"
So, in some ways, the ownership there is really "distinct"
Anyways, I don't really want to ramble. Thoughts?
Actually, let's try this:
@triagebot end-topic
Unknown Zulip user. Please add zulip-id = 232957 to your file in rust-lang/team.
:face_palm:‍♀️
lcnr has marked this topic as resolved.
lcnr has marked this topic as unresolved.
@triagebot end-topic

Does anyone have something to add on the current topic?
React with :working_on_it: if you have something to say.
React with :all_good: if not.
(It would be nice if triagebot reacted to itself)

Jack Huey said:

But types team would say "hold on a minute - there might be problems with that"

that pushes the types team pretty far into compiler territory
Well, it's a balance

Jack Huey said:

(It would be nice if triagebot reacted to itself)

it does, doesn't it, like to add the initial buttons to click on? Sometimes the reactions are slow though.
It's not necessarily "That can't be implemented"
But "Any implementation of that would have problems"
And this is actually precisely why the team is a subteam of both lang and compiler
i personally still mostly see the types team as a section of t-compiler
is the intention for us to have decision capabilities which are currently in the hands of t-lang?
That's a really good question.
It really comes back to what we "own"
And that really is the model.

lcnr said:

i personally still mostly see the types team as a section of t-compiler

Is this maybe a consequence of Rust being mostly defined by its implementation? Like if we had a Rust spec with multiple implementations, would T-types be more independent of T-compiler?
So, in a sense, somewhat

Jack Huey said:

But "Any implementation of that would have problems"

because to me this also feels like the responsibility of t-compiler, except that t-compiler currently doesn't (officially) step in until after lang made its decision
Hmm

Like if we had a Rust spec with multiple implementations, would T-types be more independent of T-compiler?

probably, we already have that a bit with rust analyser which has slightly different requirements from t-compiler iirc (e.g. with trait impls inside of functions)
So, yeah the question ownership here is important
And something that I've brought up to Niko. Specifically, as you said, what decisions does T-types make
(that are independent of T-lang)
(or T-compiler)
Maybe it's helpful to enumerate a few of the current decisions the various teams make today?
Is this best done here and now?
Or would this be better done async?
I think in the interest of time, we move on?

One way it sounds like this could work is that language changes (RFCs, MCPs, etc.) might have a list of required signoffs, and T-types would be one of those. Although I think that puts T-types more in a position of vetoing things, and it sounds like T-types wants to be more in the position of enabling things in a way that's consistent with the existing type system.
I mean, that's not a bad idea.
it seems logical to me that t-types could veto a decision, after all even if were a decision to be made to add a feature its a bit meaningless if nobody can implement it
I mean, you could imagine "team checkboxes"
I mean, it is important to note: Not every lang decisision necessarily requires integration in the model
Anyways let's pseudo triagebot end-topic on this
@triagebot end-topic

Does anyone have something to add on the current topic?
React with :working_on_it: if you have something to say.
React with :all_good: if not.
Thanks :)
Okay, so let's topic re. "traits team": What kind of precedent does this set for other team-like WGs?
This somewhat goes along with "Why is this important enough to be its own team"
that's mostly https://hackmd.io/@nikomatsakis/rJ3h_-kJc#Why-a-team-and-not-a-working-group-What-is-the-difference-between-those-anyway, isn't it?
Yes
He definitely added a bit here since I last really read through this.
TLDR: the job of T-types is never done
yes
I guess, this comes back to decision making
If T-types can make independent decisions.
Then what about other subteams?
And has an agenda
Can you elaborate on that?
Do you mean like a literal agenda?
Or "goals"
Well... I guess goals
Like we make plans
Other working groups mostly process things
Well, wg-async has plans
Would you say that should be a subteam?
Sorry, some other working groups
Or no, because the "never done" requirement isn't met?
Const eval also makes plans, llvm not so much
What about a hypothetical wg-chalk?
I think "making plans" is a good indicator of when a wg really should be a team
More of an initiative I guess? Get chalk into compiler
But, I think it's not the only criteria
(I bring this up because these are going to be the inevitable questions as this proposal progresses)
i think the three axes here are something like "how long should that group exist", "how much decision power does that group have", "is that group reactive or proactive"
Like const eval, makes plans, at some point "good enough, aka done", so not a team
Okay, so another one: wg-diagnostics
I think in reality, that's "never done"
Never done, makes plans
and to me teams feel like they should be "forever", "a lot" and "proactive"
Doesn't make decisions?
I guess, the "decision power" axis is interesting. Since I would have expected that to be a consequence of being a team, rather than a requirement

lcnr said:

and to me teams feel like they should be "forever", "a lot" and "proactive"

and after writing this down, I now finally know why i am not 100% happy with the "traits team" label. It's the lack of decision power

i think the three axes here are something like "how long should that group exist", "how much decision power does that group have", "is that group reactive or proactive"

We could make a table where these are columns and the rows are teams/wgs/initiatives
I do share that sentiment in some regards. I think T-types should have decision power, but enumerating that hasn't been done yet.
Okay, so for the sake of time, let's move on?

oli said:

i think the three axes here are something like "how long should that group exist", "how much decision power does that group have", "is that group reactive or proactive"

We could make a table where these are columns and the rows are teams/wgs/initiatives

can do that async, so let's move on, yeah ^^
Talk briefly about what these "deep dives" are
So Niko does talk a little bit about that in the doc
But when chatting with him, we came up with a couple "things that can be done"

Namely, reading through a PR (like what was done with lazy TAIT), going over a feature (maybe like GATs - how does it work), talking about a project (a-mir-formality, chalk), or reading through/discussing a piece of code (like a piece of the trait solver)
The idea being that these invite collaboratism and fresh ideas
(idk if that's a word)
I guess collaboration?
But only an hour is probably not enough for that.
How would people feel about doing 1.5 hours?
And, we'll probably start by doing text, to see how that goes. But if it's not working, maybe consider voice.
There are tough tradeoffs in both directions.
I guess since only interested parties join on deep dives, longer meetings seem good
i think even that might not be enough in all cases, so it might be worth it to do 2h and stop early most of the time
We just need to plan ahead of time who will be there
but 1.5h seems like a good start to me
Right, so I mean, the idea is anyone should feel free to join.
And we'll rotate on who "leads it"
If 1.5h isn't enough, does it make sense to maybe schedule a second follow up deep dive?
(We won't have time to go over topics, but I'll post some and we can vote. If nobody objects, Niko can start by going over a-mir-formality first)
I'm still planning on making a nice "deep dive proposal" issue template - but if you have thoughts on things you'd like to see (or lead!), please file an issue
The other thing we didn't think about, but I'm just now realizing, is this does overlap with compiler planning/steering meetings, but that's probably okay
Anyways, I think this was really productive. And we can probably call it here.
We'll start with an a-mir-formality deep dive next Friday
Thanks everyone :)
Thanks, @Jack Huey!
hey all
sorry I couldn't attend this first meeting lol

basically everything that was said feels right, and I plan to update the "types team" proposal to reflect it -- my onl caveat is @lcnr I believe that the types team should own the implementation as well. That's why I made it a dual subteam of compiler + lang
I think it was still pretty productive
in particular, I am thinking of this in a 'library-ified' world (we have to get there)
That's a really interesting point I hadn't thought of

imagine compiler was broken out into libraries; the types team would own the libraries that implement the trait system, borrow checker, type checker; other parts of the compiler team owns the libraries that are doing parsing, optimizations
I don't think that implementation + model are fully separable

I do think this is not just compiler though because model is very much lang, and as @Jack Huey said, the considerations for lang are often about more "fundamental" complexity (though sometimes it's also the specifics of our impl strategy)

Jack Huey said:

We'll start with an a-mir-formality deep dive next Friday

yay!
I'm going to think about the best structure for this :)
(deleted)
